symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
reasoning: Hypoglycemia is a common manifestation, especially in patients on glucose-lowering medication.
Urinary tract infections are more frequent due to glucosuria providing a medium for bacterial growth.
Hypertension can be a co-morbidity due to the effect of diabetes on the cardiovascular system.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
reasoning: Joint pain is a hallmark symptom.
Hypertension might be associated due to reduced mobility and possible use of corticosteroids.
Increased risk of infections, including urinary tract infections, due to immunosuppressive treatment.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
reasoning: Joint pain is a common symptom.
Renal involvement could lead to urinary tract symptoms.
May present with hypertension due to renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
reasoning: Joint pain is a manifestation.
Increased risk of infections, including urinary tract infections, due to reduced secretion of protective antibodies in body fluids.
Laryngitis can be associated with dryness of the airways.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
reasoning: Hypertension and urinary symptoms are common as the disease progresses.
Can lead to electrolyte imbalances, including those causing hypoglycemia.
Joint pain can occur due to related metabolic bone disease.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
reasoning: Hypertension is commonly associated with the metabolic syndrome component of PCOS.
Hypoglycemia may occur as a result of insulin resistance.
Urinary tract infections may be more common due to associated obesity and possible endocrine disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Gout
reasoning: Joint pain is a primary symptom due to urate crystal deposition.
Hypertension is often associated with gout, particularly as part of the metabolic syndrome.
Patients with gout may have a slightly increased risk of urinary tract infections due to chronic inflammation and possible renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders (Hypothyroidism/Hyperthyroidism)
reasoning: Hypertension can be a feature of both hypo- and hyperthyroidism.
Joint pain can be associated with hypothyroidism.
Urinary tract symptoms and hypoglycemia can occur, especially in cases of concomitant autoimmune conditions or as a result of treatment side effects.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
reasoning: Urinary tract symptoms due to neurogenic bladder.
Joint pain can occur due to musculoskeletal issues related to mobility impairment.
Hypertension may not be directly related but can occur as a secondary effect due to limited mobility or as a medication side effect.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
reasoning: Joint pain is a common symptom in the later stages.
May exhibit hypertension and hypoglycemia as part of a systemic response to infection.
Urinary tract symptoms can occur, although less commonly, depending on the spread and severity of the infection.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: Anemia and oral symptoms such as leukoplakia can be caused by nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Pernicious anemia
diagnoses.reasoning: This form of anemia is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, which can cause oral symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause chronic back pain and has been associated with anemia as part of its systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic kidney disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to anemia and contribute to bone demineralization, potentially causing back pain.

diagnoses.name: Oral squamous cell carcinoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Leukoplakia is a risk factor for oral cancers, which can cause localized oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause chronic pain, including back pain, anemia, and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Celiac disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This autoimmune disorder can cause iron deficiency anemia and has been associated with oral ulcerations.

diagnoses.name: Crohn’s disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause mouth ulcers, anemia due to malabsorption, and back pain if associated with spondyloarthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Plummer-Vinson syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by iron deficiency anemia, esophageal webs, and dysphagia, but leukoplakia can also be a manifestation.

diagnoses.name: Multiple myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause chronic back pain due to bone lesions, anemia, and renal insufficiency, which may lead to migratory edema.

diagnoses: Drug reaction (with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms, DRESS syndrome)
Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin C, Vitamin D)
Coagulation disorder (e.g., Hemophilia, Von Willebrand disease)
Eating disorders (e.g., Anorexia nervosa, Bulimia nervosa)
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Systemic lupus erythematosus, Rheumatoid arthritis)
Mental health conditions (e.g., Depression, Anxiety disorder)
Vitamin Deficiency (Vitamin B12, Vitamin C, Vitamin D)

diagnoses.name: Chemotherapy effect
diagnoses.description: Chemotherapy can cause a range of side effects including vomiting, alopecia (hair loss), and leukocytosis (increased white blood cell count). While word-finding difficulty and dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) are less typical, they can be associated due to the overall stress on the body.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus can lead to alopecia, leukocytosis as part of an inflammatory response, and neurologic symptoms such as word-finding difficulty. Dysmenorrhea and occasionally gastrointestinal symptoms like vomiting can occur.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: Though primarily associated with fatigue and pallor, severe cases can cause word-finding difficulties (due to cognitive effects), and dysmenorrhea. Vomiting can occur in the context of iron supplementation for this condition.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: PCOS can lead to menstrual irregularities such as dysmenorrhea, and it can be associated with alopecia due to hormonal imbalances. While vomiting and leukocytosis are not hallmark symptoms, they could be related to complications or concurrent conditions.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid disorder
diagnoses.description: Thyroid diseases, including hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism, can result in hair loss (alopecia) and menstrual disturbances (dysmenorrhea). Cognitive symptoms and a malfunctioning thyroid can also contribute to vague symptoms like word-finding difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines can cause vomiting and are sometimes associated with temporary cognitive symptoms such as difficulty finding words. While alopecia and dysmenorrhea are not directly caused by migraines, patients can experience more frequent migraine attacks during menstruation.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorder
diagnoses.description: Anxiety can indirectly lead to or exacerbate symptoms like difficulty finding words and vomiting. While not directly causing alopecia or leukocytosis, the stress from anxiety can worsen these conditions if they are present for other reasons.

diagnoses.name: Iron poisoning
diagnoses.description: Acute or chronic iron poisoning can cause vomiting, and in severe cases, alopecia and leukocytosis. Cognitive effects such as difficulty finding words can develop in severe cases due to iron's toxic effects on the central nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Lead poisoning
diagnoses.description: Lead poisoning can induce vomiting, cognitive difficulties including word-finding problems, and, in some cases, alopecia. Dysmenorrhea is not a classic symptom but could be an indirect consequence of the body's overall stress response.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto's)
diagnoses.description: In this condition, the immune system attacks the thyroid, which can lead to hair loss (alopecia) and menstrual irregularities such as dysmenorrhea. Cognitive symptoms including word-finding difficulty can be attributed to hypothyroidism. Vomiting is less common but can occur, especially in relation to medication or severe hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Viral infections can lead to symptoms like pneumonia and otitis media. Polycythemia may occur as a secondary response to chronic hypoxia, and lymphadenitis may develop due to the body's immune response to the virus.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Bacterial pathogens can cause pneumonia, otitis media, and lymphadenitis. Secondary polycythemia might occur due to chronic hypoxia from severe pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune conditions can lead to generalized inflammation causing dysmenorrhea and lymphadenitis, and could potentially influence the development of polycythemia through chronic inflammation or hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Diseases such as sarcoidosis can cause lymphadenitis and polycythemia. Given their inflammatory nature, they could also potentially lead to symptoms such as dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Tuberculosis can lead to pneumonia and lymphadenitis. The chronic nature of the disease might contribute to polycythemia due to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Lymphoma could explain lymphadenitis and, through systemic effects, might contribute to polycythemia. Secondary infections might account for pneumonia and otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Myeloproliferative disorders could directly cause polycythemia. They might also predispose an individual to infections such as pneumonia and mediate inflammatory responses leading to symptoms like lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, making individuals more susceptible to pneumonia, lymphadenitis, and otitis media. Polycythemia could arise as a secondary phenomenon related to chronic disease.

diagnoses.name: Sickle Cell Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Sickle cell disease can predispose individuals to infections like pneumonia and otitis media due to asplenia or hyposplenia. Lymphadenitis and polycythemia could occur as complications or secondary phenomena.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic liver disease can lead to conditions like polycythemia through altered hormone metabolism. Secondary infections such as pneumonia and conditions like lymphadenitis could occur as complications.

diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation with allergic component

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain accompanied by visual disturbances, numbness, weakness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms include headache, difficulty speaking, and paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms include numbness, weakness, balance issues, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, difficulty speaking, weakness, and sensory changes.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Symptoms can start as weakness and tingling in the extremities and can rapidly spread, leading to paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, stiffness, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can cause speech difficulty, paralysis, and headache but usually resolves within a few hours without any lasting symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs. Symptoms can vary and may include headaches, fatigue, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that affects skeletal muscle strength by impeding the communication between nerves and muscles, leading to symptoms such as weakness and slurred speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: An abscess is a collection of pus that has built up within the tissue of the body. A brain abscess is a rare and potentially life-threatening condition, where a pus-filled swelling develops in the brain. Symptoms often include headache, fever, nausea, and weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often on one side of the head. Patients can experience speech disturbances (aphasia), sensitivity to sound (phonophobia), and visual phenomena such as flashes of light or zigzag patterns (scintillation).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can manifest with aphasia, weakness on one side of the body, and visual disturbances, but does not lead to long-term brain damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may result in symptoms such as weakness on one side of the body, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine without Aura
diagnoses.description: A common type of migraine characterized by a severe headache, usually on one side of the head, but does not include the visual or neurological disturbances (aura) seen in migraine with aura. Phonophobia is a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can manifest with a wide range of neurological symptoms depending on its location. These may include headaches, seizures, weakness, aphasia, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). Symptoms can vary widely and may include fatigue, weakness, visual disturbances, and difficulty with coordination and speech.

diagnoses.name: Hemiplegic Migraine
diagnoses.description: A rare form of migraine where individuals experience a migraine accompanied by paralysis or weakness on one side of the body (hemiplegia), aphasia, and visual disturbances similar to those seen in migraine with aura.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Aphasic and sensory disturbances might occur in focal seizures.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, usually caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, stiffness of the neck, and sensitivity to light (photophobia) and sound (phonophobia).

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain tissue, often due to a viral infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, confusion, seizures, and sensory or motor disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances (aura), such as flashes of light or blind spots, as well as sensitivity to sound (phonophobia). Migraine aura can also include other sensory disturbances like numbness and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. Symptoms can include weakness, numbness, severe headache, and problems with vision such as scintillations.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, numbness, weakness, and visual disturbances. Immediate medical attention is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system. It can cause symptoms such as numbness, weakness, problems with vision including scintillation, and sometimes phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can cause symptoms like headache, numbness, weakness, and visual disturbances, depending on its location.

diagnoses.name: Seizure Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders that cause uncontrolled electrical disturbances in the brain. Symptoms can vary and may include numbness, weakness, and sensory disturbances like scintillation.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inner ear disorder that can lead to dizziness and hearing loss. In some cases, sufferers may experience headache and sensory disturbances, although these are less common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Crisis
diagnoses.description: A severe increase in blood pressure that can cause symptoms like severe headache, visual disturbances, numbness, and weakness. Immediate medical attention is needed to prevent a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, usually in the head, that can cause severe headaches, jaw pain, visual disturbances, and sometimes symptoms like numbness and weakness when it affects certain vascular territories.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Symptoms can include brief episodes of numbness or weakness, and in some types, visual phenomena such as scintillation.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with ITP)
Systemic Sclerosis with renal and central nervous system involvement
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Evans syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with ITP)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
